p: Complete blood count, coagulation profile, and serum biochemical tests are routinely performed for COVID-19 patients [ 12]. Lymphocytopenia is a common finding and the percentage of lymphocytes (LYM%) has been suggested as a predictive parameter during disease course. Patients with LYM% < 20 % on day 10–12 after symptom onset tend to have worse outcomes with higher mortality among those with LYM < 5 % [ 13]. A preliminary study proposed a neutrophil-to-lymphocyte ratio (NLR) of ≥ 3.13 as a predictor of severe disease specially in patients above 50 years old, and the authors recommended that these patients should be admitted early to intensive care units (ICU) [ 14].
